awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Structural and Biophysical Studies of Bacterial Copper Acquisition and Regulation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  In this project, funded by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and housed in the Chemistry Division, Professor Oriana Fisher and her students at Lehigh University will study the behavior of copper ions in bacteria using a wide range of chemical and biochemical techniques.  The research will provide a detailed understanding of how bacteria process copper, and this will help lead to a better understanding of the chemistry of antibiotic resistance.  Dr. Fisher’s plan to pilot a summer research program that will recruit students from groups underrepresented in science will broaden participation in chemistry at Lehigh and will provide long-term mentoring of a cohort of underrepresented minority students as they navigate the transition from undergraduate the graduate school. 

Professor Fisher will biophysically and structurally elucidate proteins that orchestrate copper acquisition in Bacillus subtilis, with the aims of elucidating how Cu is recognized and chaperoned extracellularly and investigating the structural and biophysical basis for transcriptional control of the ycn operon, which may hold a key to understanding bacterial copper acquisition and regulation.  While copper export proteins are highly conserved throughout evolution, copper importers in bacteria appear to be completely distinct from their eukaryotic counterparts. Previous studies have focused on this problem
primarily from a biological perspective; research under this award will provide new insight into a molecular level understanding of proteins that govern these processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The major goals of this award were to investigate proteins that carry out copper acquisition in the bacterium Bacillus subtilis. The ycn operon of B. subtilis encodes a trio of proteins that have been implicated in copper acquisition and regulation, but their structure, metal-binding properties, and biochemistry had not been elucidated. During the award period, several key advances were made. The three dimensional structures and copper binding preferences of several domains within the Ycn proteins were elucidated. This included identifying an important structural role for a conserved tryptophan residue in the YcnI protein that helps to confer the protein’s very high affinity for Cu(II), as well as foundational studies that suggest functional roles for the extracellular regions of the Ycn proteins. Overall, these studies provided data that has served to illuminate how the proteins encoded by the ycn interact with metal ions and how those interactions may lead to biological consequences. These studies will serve as a foundation for future work to investigate the biochemical and molecular details of how copper is used and regulated in B. subtilis as well as other mircroorganisms. This work has resulted in two publications to date, with additional publications reporting the results of the award anticipated.

 

Broader Impacts:

This award provided training opportunities for a postdoctoral fellow, a graduate student, and 6 undergraduate students (most of whom are currently pursuing PhDs or are in postbaccalaureate programs). Three of these individuals have presented their research at national or international conferences, and three have co-authored peer-reviewed publications. The award also enabled the development of the Biochemistry Opportunities for Undergraduate Scientists (BOUNDS) program. This program provided an immersive mentored summer research experience in Biochemistry and support for preparing competitive applications for graduate programs. Two students worked in the PI’s laboratory as part of this program in Summer 2023, culminating in a poster session with other undergraduate researchers on campus. The BOUNDS program also held a series of both in-person and Zoom workshops for these and other students from Eastern PA on topics including navigating imposter syndrome, preparing graduate school applications, and informational sessions with practicing scientists in various biochemistry-related careers.
